ArticleInfo.ArticleTitle: Enhanced photocatalytic activity of In2O3-decorated TiO2

Affiliation.OrgDivision: Key Laboratory of Green Catalysis of Higher Education Institutes of Sichuan, College of Chemistry and Pharmaceutical Engineering
Affiliation.OrgName: Sichuan University of Science and Engineering

Abstract.Heading: Abstract
Abstract.Para: Titania (TiO2)-based photocatalysts decorated with different amounts of indium oxide (In2O3) were prepared by a pore impregnating method and characterized by the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) method, X-ray diffraction (XRD), UV–Vis diffuse reflectance spectroscopy (DRS), and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). The separation efficiency of photogenerated charges was investigated using benzoquinone (BQ) as scavenger. The activities of the photocatalysts were evaluated by decolorization of methyl orange (MO) aqueous solution under ultraviolet-light irradiation. Compared to TiO2, In2O3/TiO2 composites show improved photocatalytic performance due to the coupling effect of TiO2 and In2O3, which greatly improves the separation of photogenerated electrons and holes.

Section1.Heading: Introduction
Section1.Para: Heterogeneous photocatalytic oxidation of organic contaminants by semiconductor photocatalysts has attracted increasing attention [1, 2]. Among the semiconductors investigated, titania (TiO2) is a promising material for environmental purification due to strong UV-light absorption, strong oxidation property, low cost, nontoxicity, and excellent photostability [3–5]. However, the fast recombination of the photogenerated electron/hole (e−/h+) pairs reduces the photonic efficiency and represents a major bottleneck for the photocatalytic applications of TiO2 [6, 7]. Until now, tremendous efforts have been developed to enhance the photocatalytic performance of TiO2 [8]. Among these approaches, an effective and simple strategy is by construction of heterojunctions. Heterojunctions have great potential in tuning the desired electronic properties of the composite photocatalysts and can efficiently separate the photogenerated electron–hole pairs [9, 10]. When a heterojunction is irradiated with UV light, valence-band (VB) electrons are excited to the conduction band (CB) with simultaneous generation of the same amount of holes in the VB. Photogenerated electrons are then injected from the CB of the semiconductor with an energetically higher CB edge to the CB of the semiconductor with a lower CB edge. Simultaneously, holes are injected in the opposite direction for appropriate VB offsets, thus increasing the efficiency of charge separation and reducing the recombination of electron–hole pairs [11]. Coupling of different semiconductors with different energies has received great interest in the past decade and some heterostructures exhibit higher photocatalytic activity than TiO2 alone [8].

As an n-type semiconductor with an indirect band gap of about 2.9 eV [12, 13], In2O3 has been widely used in many fields such as window heaters, solar cells, flat panel display materials, and gas sensors [14]. In2O3/TiO2 heterojunctions have been studied by many groups. Mu et al. prepared In2O3–TiO2 heterojunctions with high visible-light photocatalytic activity by a simple combination of an electrospinning technique and a solvothermal process [15]. Guo and coworkers prepared a metallic Ag and semiconductor In2O3 codoped TiO2 photocatalyst by a one-step sol–gel–solvothermal method [16]. At 2.0 % Ag and 1.9 % In2O3 doping, photocatalytic activity of the Ag/In2O3–TiO2 three-component system to rhodamine B and methyl ter-butyl ether degradation outperformed as-prepared single- and two-component systems as well as commercial TiO2. Chen et al. investigated interfacial charge carrier dynamics of the In2O3–TiO2–Pt three-component heterojunction system [17]. The research demonstrated that electron transfer from In2O3, through TiO2, and eventually to Pt was achieved, resulting in an outstanding charge-separation property for the as-prepared heterojunctions. Chakraborty and Kebede fabricated In2O3/TiO2 heterojunctions with high visible-light photocatalytic activity by utilizing maleic acid as an organic linker to combine In2O3 and Degussa P25 (TiO2) nanoparticles [18]. However, the effects of the photoinduced charge-separation efficiency, the hydroxyl content, and the loading of In2O3 on the photocatalytic performance of In2O3/TiO2 heterojunctions prepared by the pore impregnating method have been seldom addressed.

The objective of this work is to study the effect of the coupling of In2O3 with TiO2 on the photocatalytic performance of catalysts. The photocatalytic performance was studied by decolorization of methyl orange (MO) aqueous solution under ultraviolet-light irradiation.

Section2.Heading: Preparation of photocatalysts
Section2.Para: All chemicals (analytical grade reagents) were supplied from Chengdu Kelong Chemical Reagent Factory and used as received. A mixed solution of tetrabutylorthotitanate (10 mL) and ethanol (10 mL) was added dropwise to 100 mL deionized water under stirring. The precipitate obtained was filtered, washed with ethanol, dried, and then baked in air at 723 K for 2 h in a muffle furnace.

In2O3/TiO2 samples with different In2O3 loadings were prepared by a pore impregnating method using In(NO3)3 solution. Briefly, 5 g as-prepared TiO2 was put in a beaker, water was added and made the TiO2 humidified (no water was observed on the surface of TiO2) assisted by ultrasonics; the volume of the water is the water pore volume of 5 g TiO2. The desired In(NO3)3⋅5H2O was dissolved in water (the water pore volume of 5 g TiO2); then 5 g TiO2 was added into the In(NO3)3 solution mentioned above and ultrasonically dispersed for 20 min. After that, the mixture was kept in a static condition for 1 h and then dried at 373 K overnight. Finally, the powders were heated in air at 573 K for 2 h. In this way, In2O3-decorated TiO2 samples with different molar ratios of In/Ti were prepared. The samples with different molar ratios of In/Ti (0 %, 1 %, 2 %, 3 %, 4 %, 5 %, 6 %, and 20 %) were named as follows: TiO2, 1 % In, 2 % In, 3 % In, 4 % In, 5 % In, 6 % In, and 20 % In, respectively. In2O3 was prepared by thermal decomposition of In(NO3)3⋅5H2O at 573 K for 2 h.

Section2.Heading: Characterization of the photocatalysts
Section2.Para: The specific surface area and pore size measurements were performed on a SSA-4200 automatic surface analyzer (Builder, China). The solid samples were evacuated at 523 K for 1 h and then cooled to 77 K using liquid N2 at which point N2 adsorption was measured. X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were recorded on a DX-2600 X-ray diffractometer using Cu Kα (λ=0.15406 nm) radiation and equipped with a graphite monochromator. The X-ray tube was operated at 40 kV and 25 mA. Samples were scanned from 2θ equal to 10∘ up to 90∘ and the X-ray diffraction line positions were determined with a step size of 0.03∘. UV–Vis diffuse reflectance spectroscopy (DRS) was carried out using a TU-1907 UV–Vis spectrophotometer equipped with an integrating sphere; BaSO4 was used as the reference. Scanning electron microscope (SEM) images were taken with a JSM-7500F scanning electron microscope (JEOL, Japan) using an accelerating voltage of 5 kV. Before SEM measurement, the sample was dispersed in water assisted by ultrasonics for 10 min and then gold plating was performed. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) was carried out on a Tecnai F20 (FEI, America) electron microscope at an accelerating voltage of 200 kV. Samples for TEM analysis were prepared by drying a drop of sample dispersion in absolute EtOH on carbon-coated copper grids. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements were performed on an XSAM 800 using Mg Kα radiation at 12 kV and 12 mA. The X-ray photoelectron spectra were referenced to the C1s peak (BE=284.80 eV) resulting from adventitious hydrocarbons (i.e. from the XPS instrument itself) present on the sample surface.

Section2.Heading: Evaluation of the photocatalytic activity
Section2.Para: All photocatalytic decolorization experiments were performed in a SGY-II photochemical reactor (Kai Feng HXSCI Science Instrument Factory, China). The irradiation source was a 500 W high-pressure mercury lamp with a maximum emitting radiation wavelength of 365 nm; the lamp was encapsulated in a cooling quartz jacket and positioned in the middle of the reactor. Quartz test tubes were located around the lamp and the distance from the lamp to the quartz test tubes was 10 cm. The initial concentration of MO aqueous solution was 10 mg/L. 50 mg of the prepared photocatalyst was added into 50 mL MO solution and the reaction mixture was continuously aerated by a pump to provide oxygen and aid in the mixing of the reaction solution. The decolorization reaction was performed at room temperature. The pH value of the reaction solution was 7.0. After 1 h, the samples were removed and centrifuged (6000 rpm) to separate the photocatalyst for analysis. The concentration of MO was measured by a 756 PC spectrophotometer at 460 nm and analyzed by the Lambert–Beer law. All reported data were the average values of three parallel determinations.

Section1.Heading: Results and discussion
Section1.Para:
In heterogeneous photocatalysis, the photocatalytic performance of the catalyst not only depends on the chemical properties of the loading species but also on the amount of the loaded compound. Table 1 shows the surface parameters of photocatalysts with different In2O3 loadings.

The highest specific surface area and pore volume are obtained when In loading is 5 mol% (In/Ti). However, considering the measurement error of specific surface area (±5 m2 g−1), the specific surface areas of 4 % In, 5 % In, and 6 % In have no obvious difference; this result demonstrates that the In2O3 amount is not effective for changing the specific surface area of In2O3/TiO2. A more detailed mechanism needs to be further investigated in the near future. The relatively higher Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) surface area can facilitate more efficient contact of the photocatalyst with organic molecules, which accelerates the photocatalytic decolorization of MO.

The XRD patterns of the photocatalysts are shown in Fig. 1.
Fig. 1
XRD patterns of photocatalysts

As shown in Fig. 1, for TiO2, all strong peaks can be indexed as the pure anatase-type TiO2, which agrees well with the reported data (JCPDS No. 89-4921). No other peaks can be observed, indicating a high purity of the as-prepared TiO2 samples. For the In2O3/TiO2 (In/Ti≤6 %) sample, the XRD patterns resemble that of pure TiO2. No peaks of In2O3 were detected by XRD in the 2θ region from 20∘ to 60∘. We believe that this could be attributed to two factors: (1) the deposited In2O3 is highly dispersed in the support matrix and (2) the percentage of In2O3 is very low. It is known that the Ti4+ ionic radius is 0.068 nm and the In3+ ionic radius is 0.081 nm; it is impossible for the In3+ ions to enter into the crystal cell of TiO2 through an interstitial mode [19], so the forming of In2O3–TiO2 alloy can be excluded. To further support this conclusion, XRD patterns of 20 % In are presented. As shown in Fig. 1, for the 20 % In sample, only In2O3 and TiO2 were detected; no XRD patterns of In2TiO5 were detected. Rozdin et al. reported that titanium and indium precursors interact to form In2TiO5 at temperatures above 1123 K [20]. Moreover, compared with TiO2, no obvious shift of diffraction angles was observed for In2O3/TiO2 samples. The XRD results show that the In2O3 loaded is on the surface of TiO2; In2O3/TiO2 samples are composed of two single phases of In2O3 and TiO2 in our case.

Figure 2 shows diffuse reflectance spectra of TiO2 and In2O3/TiO2. Due to the partial overlap of the diffuse reflectance spectra of In2O3/TiO2, only the diffuse reflectance spectra of TiO2 and 5 % In are presented.
Fig. 2
UV–Vis diffuse reflectance spectra of photocatalysts and estimated band gap of In2O3 by the Kubelka–Munk function (inset)

As shown in Fig. 2, diffuse reflectance spectra of TiO2 and 5 % In have no obvious difference. Compared with TiO2, no red shift was observed for In2O3/TiO2; the result above indicates that In2O3-impregnated TiO2 cannot be driven by visible light. This is different from what has been reported by Mu and coworkers [15], who fabricated In2O3–TiO2 with high visible-light photocatalytic activity by a simple combination of an electrospinning technique and a solvothermal process. Chakraborty and Kebede prepared In2O3/TiO2 heterojunctions with high visible-light photocatalytic activity by utilizing maleic acid as an organic linker to combine In2O3 and Degussa P25 (TiO2) nanoparticles [18]. The different photocatalytic activities may be due to the preparation methods and treatment temperatures. The estimated band gap of In2O3 by the Kubelka–Munk function is about 2.94 eV, which fits well with the value reported in Refs. [12, 13].

The morphology of the photocatalysts plays an important role in influencing the photocatalytic activity. The SEM and TEM images of the prepared photocatalysts are shown in Fig. 3. As shown in Fig. 3, all photocatalysts are irregular lump- and wormhole-like; the surface is not smooth. Furthermore, compared with TiO2, relatively abundant pores can be observed for 5 % In; the abundant pores are beneficial to the higher specific surface area, as demonstrated in Table 1. Figure 3e and f show that the segments of the irregular lump- and wormhole-like In2O3/TiO2 are composed of nanoparticles with the size of approx. 10 nm.
Fig. 3
(a, b, c, d) SEM and (e, f) TEM images of photocatalysts: (a) TiO2; (b) 3 % In; (c) 5 % In; (d) 6 % In; (e) TiO2; (f) 5 % In

X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was carried out to determine the surface chemical composition of TiO2 and In2O3/TiO2 as well as the valence states of various species. As shown in Fig. 4, two XPS spectra reveal characteristic peaks for Ti, O, and C. The 5 % In XPS spectrum was detected. Figure 5 shows high-resolution XPS spectra of the Ti 2p3/2 region taken on the surface of TiO2 and In2O3/TiO2. For TiO2, the peak located at 458.5 eV is assigned to Ti 2p3/2, indicating a normal state of Ti4+. However, for In2O3/TiO2, although there is a slight shift of the Ti 2p value, considering the measurement error (±0.1 eV), the peaks for Ti 2p3/2 of In2O3/TiO2 composites have no obvious difference compared with TiO2, which indicates that the effect of In2O3 on the chemical environments of the Ti element is so small that it can be ignored due to the low In content. Wang and coworkers observed similar results when they prepared titania modified by nitrogen and indium [21].
Fig. 4
XPS survey spectra for the surfaces of two photocatalysts
Fig. 5
High-resolution XPS spectra of Ti 2p on the surface of photocatalysts

Figure 6 reveals high-resolution XPS spectra for In 3d. The In 3d5/2 XPS peak of In2O3 has a characteristic peak centered at a binding energy of 444.2 eV [15]; compared with the reported In 3d5/2 signal of metallic indium, which appears at 443.6 eV, the absence of this peak excludes the existence of metallic indium. This result indicates that the elemental indium in In2O3/TiO2 composites exists in the oxide state only. However, the 3d5/2 peak of 3 % In, 5 % In, and 6 % In shifts to higher values compared to 444.2 eV, confirming that an interaction between In2O3 and TiO2 exists. The O 1s XPS spectrum can be resolved using the XPS peak fitting program. Figure 7 presents the O 1s photoelectron peaks. For TiO2, there exist only two oxygen signals located at 529.6 and 532.0 eV, which are attributed to Ti–O–Ti (lattice O) and Ti–OH, respectively [22]. Hydroxyl group signals found in TiO2 and In2O3/TiO2 are attributable to the chemically adsorbed H2O [23], which can react with TiO2 to form Ti–OH, such as H2O+Ti–O–Ti→2 Ti–OH [24]. The In2O3/TiO2 samples are composed of two single phases of In2O3 and TiO2 in our case; thus, for the In2O3/TiO2 photocatalysts, the O 1s XPS spectrum could be resolved into three kinds of oxygen, Ti–O, O–H, and In–O, respectively. Oxygen anions from indium oxide appear at 530.7 eV [25].
Fig. 6
High-resolution XPS spectra of In 3d on the surface of photocatalysts
Fig. 7
High-resolution XPS spectra of the O 1s region on the surfaces of photocatalysts: (a) TiO2; (b) 3 % In; (c) 5 % In; (d) 6 % In

Table 2 lists the curve-fitting results of O 1s XPS spectra for the photocatalysts (Fig. 7), where r
i (%) represents the ratio of the different kinds of oxygen contributions. As indicated in Table 2, the hydroxyl content on In2O3/TiO2 is greater than on TiO2. Usually, the increase of hydroxyl content on the surface of TiO2 is beneficial to the enhancement of photocatalytic performance [24, 26]. This result can be further confirmed by the results of photocatalytic activity.

In an attempt to elucidate the reactive species and separation efficiency of photogenerated charges, the effects of different scavengers on the photocatalytic decolorization of MO were investigated. The scavengers used in this study are ammonium oxalate (AO) for h+ [27], isopropanos l (IPA) for
[28], and benzoquinone (BQ) for
[29]. As a consequence of quenching, the photocatalytic decolorization efficiency of MO will be lower. The more MO conversion efficiency is reduced by a scavenger, the more important role the corresponding reactive species plays in the photocatalytic decolorization reaction. The effects of a series of scavengers on the photocatalytic decolorization efficiency of MO are shown in Fig. 8. The photocatalytic decolorization efficiency of MO drops rapidly from 40.4 % to 21.4 % after adding BQ, indicating that
is the main active species in the photocatalytic decolorization process. When AO and IPA are added, the photocatalytic decolorization efficiency of MO drops to 33.5 % and 29.7 %, respectively, which indicates that
and h+ play a secondary important role in the oxidation of MO.
Fig. 8
Effects of a series of scavengers on the MO conversion over TiO2 (illumination time = 60 min, scavenger dosage = 0.2 mmol/L)

To further deduce the separation efficiency of photogenerated charges of all photocatalysts, the effect of BQ (0.2 mmol/L) on the photocatalytic decolorization efficiency of MO over different photocatalysts was investigated. The results are presented in Fig. 9.
Fig. 9
Effects of BQ on the MO conversion over photocatalysts (illumination time = 60 min, BQ dosage = 0.2 mmol/L)

As shown in Fig. 9, the presence of BQ partly suppresses the photocatalytic decolorization of MO. However, the decolorization efficiency of MO over 5 % In is still the highest, which indicates that the 5 % In sample possesses the highest separation efficiency of photogenerated charges in the photocatalytic reaction to some extent. The separation efficiency of photogenerated charges gradually increases with increasing In content, reaches a maximum when the In content is 5 %, and then drops at 6 %. Compared with other samples, the 5 % In sample possesses more charge carriers to participate in the photocatalytic reaction, which has a beneficial effect on the photocatalytic performance of the catalyst.

On the basis of the above results, a proposed mechanism can be discussed to explain the enhancement of the photocatalytic properties of the In2O3/TiO2 composites. In2O3 is a narrow band gap semiconductor. Its conduction-band position is about −0.62 V (vs. NHE: Normal Hydrogen Electrode); the CB of In2O3 is located above the top of the CB band of TiO2 (−0.29 V) by 0.33 V (vs. NHE) [30]. Thus, for In2O3/TiO2 composites, TiO2 can serve as an effective electron scavenger for the surface-attached In2O3 due to its lower conduction-band potential than that of In2O3. As a consequence, the photogenerated electrons can accumulate on TiO2 and the photogenerated holes can accumulate on In2O3, thus increasing the efficiency of charge separation. Dissolved oxygen molecules react with the electrons (e−) on the surface of TiO2 to yield superoxide radical anions
$\mathrm{O}_{2}^{\bullet-}$ , and then further generate hydroperoxyl radicals (
), producing a hydroxyl radical
that is a strong oxidizing agent that decomposes MO [31]. At the same time, holes in the VB of In2O3 have powerful potential to oxidize MO directly. In short,
$\mathrm{O}_{2}^{\bullet-}$ , h+, and
are the active species that effectively react with MO. The photoexcited electron–hole separation process is shown in Fig. 11.
Fig. 11
Schematic diagram of photoexcited electron–hole separation process

In fact, all related factors (such as the specific surface area, the hydroxyl content, the charge-separation efficiency, and so on) influence the photocatalytic activity. As a whole, 5 % In possesses the best photocatalytic activity and the TiO2 sample possesses the worst photocatalytic activity among the experimental compositions. In this paper, the improved photocatalytic activity of In2O3/TiO2 may be attributed to the coupling effect of TiO2 and In2O3.

Section1.Heading: Conclusions
Section1.Para:
In2O3/TiO2 composite photocatalysts with different molar percentages of In2O3 were successfully prepared by a facile pore impregnating method. The photocatalytic activity of In2O3/TiO2 composites is much higher than that of pure TiO2. The optimal In content in the composite is 5 mol% (In/Ti). The photocatalytic decolorization efficiency of MO over 5 % In is more than two times that over TiO2. The enhanced photocatalytic activity of the composites originates from the coupling effect of TiO2 and In2O3.
and
$\mathrm{O}_{2}^{\bullet-}$ reactive radicals generated in the CB of TiO2 play an important role in the photocatalytic decolorization of MO by In2O3/TiO2 composite systems as well as in the direct h+ attack in the VB of In2O3.
